occurrences.line_text: To bring her backe againe, or worke her finall bale.
Monstrous mishapt, and all his backe was spect
That almost in the backe he oft her strake:
Thence backe returning to the former land,
Late forth she sent, she backe returning spyde,
With that same Squyre, returned backe againe
But if it should not grieue you, backe agayne
Of th'inland folke, which sought him backe to driue,
He turned backe, and would haue fled arere;
Gratious respect, thy wife shall backe be sent,
Ne euer looked backe for good or ill,
She turned her, and returned backe againe:
And turning backe to Scudamour, thus sayd;
And backe retire, all scorcht and pitifully brent.
Through the greene gras his long bright burnisht backe declares.
Which doen, he backe retyred soft away,
That at his backe a brode Capuccio had,
For from her backe her garments she did teare,
Those cursed leaues, his charmes backe to reuerse;
Returning backe, those goodly roomes, which erst
Which who so list looke backe to former ages,
About her backe and all her bodie wound;
The other backe retired, and contrarie trode.
And thrise he drew it backe: so did at last forbeare.
He looked backe, and her aduizing well,
And with such furie backe at him it heft,
Backe to retire, and somewhat to relent,
Driues backe the current of his kindly course,
But when the floud is spent, then backe againe
Who backe returning, told as he had seene,
So sore, that tombling backe, he downe did slyde
Adowne her backe, the which it fairely blest
That quite it chynd his backe behind the sell,
And backe returned with right heauie mind,
Backe to that desert forrest they retyred,
When suddenly behind her backe she heard
That ere she backe could turne to taken heed,
She looking backe, espies that griesly wight
And forst him backe with fowle dishonor to retreat.
Vnto those woods he turned backe againe,
Loe hard behind his backe his foe was prest,
The better had, and bet the others backe,
With bowed backe, by reason of the lode,
Her goodly lockes adowne her backe did flow
Till like a victor on his backe he ride,
Backe to him selfe he gan returne the blame,
So backe he came vnto her patient;
He bad him stay, and backe with him retire;
Else he doth hold him backe or beat away.
Could swim like to a fish, whiles he his backe bestrad.
His horses backe, for dread of being drownd,
So backe he brought Sir Marinell againe;
Which when he had perform'd, then backe againe
But Talus by the backe the boaster hent,
And drawing backe deceiued their intent;
So backe againe they homeward turnd their feete.
Then backe returning, where his Dame did lie,
But that the Goddesse with her rod him backe did beat.
His horses backe, yet to and fro long shooke,
And made him backe againe as fast to fly;
That backe againe vpon themselues they turned,
And backe with both his hands vnto him hayles
That brought her backe. And comming present there,
Ne none can backe returne, that once are gone amis.
And on his backe an vncouth vestiment
Als at his backe a great wyde net he bore,
He ere he could his weapon backe repaire,
That backe she would haue turnd for great affright.
But ere that it she backe againe had borne,
For soone as he their outrage backe doth beat,
Backe to recule; vntill that yron man
That forst at first those knights backe to retyre:
That by no meanes it backe againe he forth could wrast.
Tho as he backe returned from that land,
And tribute backe repay as to their King.
Brought aunswere backe, that ere he tasted bread,
Which I no lesse disdayning, backe returned
After long search and chauff, he turned backe
Then turning backe vnto that gentle boy,
And turne we backe to good Sir Calidore;
To beare this burden on your dainty backe;
Whom on his backe he bore, till he him brought
Or beare her on thy backe with pleasing payne,
Behinde his Ladies backe, who to him cryde,
That forst him backe recoyle, and reele areare;
He wearie woxe, and backe return'd againe
He with him thought backe to returne againe:
Tho backe returning to that sorie Dame,
And all the while his backe for best safegard,
That soone as he returned backe againe,
Was at his backe with heartlesse heedinesse,
Therefore descending backe in haste, he sought
Tooke surer hould, and from his horses backe
Backe to the place, where Turpine late he lore;
He would haue backe retyred from that sight,
Backe to the place, whereas his Lord he sleeping vew'd.
But turne we now backe to that Ladie free,
And maugre all his might, backe to relent:
His mindes sad message backe vnto him sent;
And with his club bet backe his brondyron bright
Rebeaten backe vpon him selfe againe,
And eeke this wallet at your backe arreare,
Then turning backe vnto that captiue thrall,
From them returning to that Ladie backe,
Backe to the furrow which I lately left;
Tho backe returning to my sheepe againe,
I shal resolue, or backe to turne againe,
He backe returned to his rusticke wonne,
And bringeth backe againe.
To call the soule backe to her home againe;
And turne we backe to Calidore, where we him found.
Who when he backe returned from the wood,
Then backe returning to his dearest deare,
Yet durst he not draw backe; nor once withstand
He does backebite, and spightfull poison spues
With which some wicked tongues did it backebite,
To tame, and ryde their backes not made to beare;
But th'head fell backeward on the continent.
Th'one forward looking, th'other backeward bent,
So as I entred, I did backeward looke,
And euer as she rode, her eye was backeward bent.
So backeward he attone with him did wend.
He lent against a tree, that backeward onset bard.
That backeward he enforced him to fall:
Was close conuaid, and to the back-gate brought,
Does ride on both their backs, & faire her selfe doth saue.
Such as behind their backs (so backward bred)
But she backstarting with disdainefull yre,
And with the Lady backward sought to wend;
Their backward bent knees teach her humbly to obay.
So backward still was turnd his wrincled face,
Still as he fled, his eye was backward cast,
Or backward turne his course from heauens hight;
A little backward for his best defence,
As he recoyled backward, in the mire
Ne backward shrinke, but as a stedfast towre,
Him backward ouerthrew, and downe him stayd
Still as she fled, her eye she backward threw,
And though oft looking backward, well she vewd,
And with sterne horrour backward gan to start:
But when againe he backward cast his eye,
Still fled he forward, looking backward still,
Tho as she backward cast her busie eye,
That with the force it backward forced him to bow.
As fast as forward erst, now backward to retrate.
That she him forced backward to retreat,
Such as behind their backs (so backward bred)
Of her fierce wrath, and backward still retyre,
Ere to his den he backward could recoyle,
But Talus soone him ouertooke, and backward drew.
The warie foule his bill doth backward wring;
Simple in shew, and voyde of malice bad,
He bad awake blacke Plutoes griesly Dame,
A bold bad man, that dar'd to call by name
Vnto that Elfin knight he bad him fly,
And bad her knight addresse him to the fray:
Her soone he ouertooke, and bad to stay,
Of one bad sire, whose youngest is Sans ioy,
Thither Duessa bad him bend his pace:
That with their counsels bad her kingdome did vphold.
Of Princesse worthy, scarse them bad arise.
So euery good to bad he doth abuse:
And bad say on the secret of her hart.
And vnto battaill bad them selues addresse:
To make one great by others losse, is bad excheat.
Then wonne from death, she bad him tellen plaine
And sternely bad him other businesse plie,
And bad the waters, which from her did flow,
Till all vnweeting, an Enchaunter bad
From loftie steede, and bad the Ladie stay,
On you hath fround, and pourd his influence bad,
So as she bad, that witch they disaraid,
Whose aunswere bad me still assured bee,
She to me made, and bad me loue her deare,
And bad him choose, what death he would desire:
All were his earthly eyen both blunt and bad,
Then bad the knight his Lady yede aloofe,
He bad to open wyde his brazen gate,
Yet sparckling fire, and bad thereof take heed;
Bad on that Messenger rude hands to reach.
And bad tell on the tenor of his plaint;
On them she workes her will to vses bad:
And bad me call Lucina to me neare.
To good and bad, the common Inne of rest;
As selfe to dyen bad, vnburied bad to beene.
As selfe to dyen bad, vnburied bad to beene.
Her lowd gainsaid, and both their champions bad
But that their natures bad appeard in both:
They both nigh were, and each bad other flie:
And euer bad him stay, till time the tide renewd.
Mortall Samnitis, and Cicuta bad,
That bad him come in haste. He by and by
Bad therefore I him deeme, that thus lies dead on field.
Good or bad (gan his brother fierce reply)
Or what doth his bad death now satisfy
As him the Steward bad. They both attone
At last ripe age bad him surrender late
Bad counsels, prayses, and false flatteries.
Backe to the world, bad liuers to torment:
Which Guyon hearing, streight his Palmer bad,
That he the boateman bad row easily,
As if that age bad him that burden spare,
Bad those same sixe forbeare that single enimy.
He bad tell on; and then she thus began.
And bad her all things put in readinesse anon.
Bad her old Squire vnlace her lofty creast;
Bad her from womankind to keepe him well:
His mother bad him womens loue to hate,
Arose, she bad her charet to be brought,
Bad eke attonce their charets to be sought;
Which wast begot in heauen, but for thy bad
Of his bad deeds, which dayly he increast,
Vnweeting of their wile and treason bad,
Him boldly bad his passage there to stay,
The bitter earth, and bad to let him in
For nathemore for that spectacle bad,
Through which he follow should his brethren bad,
That bad them to increase and multiply:
Bad her commaund my life to saue, or spill.
Eftsoones she bad me, with incessaunt paine
Bad that same boaster, as he mote, on high
Who thereto answering, said; the tydings bad,
But neuer let th'ensample of the bad
As ignoraunt of seruants bad abuse,
And bad, that none their ioyous treason should reueale.
And bad before his soueraine Lord appere:
Had it purloyned for his maister bad:)
This all as bad as she, and worse, if worse ought were.
They after both, and boldly bad him bace,
And bad the stubborne flames to yield him way:
His blindfold eyes he bad a while vnbind,
Of the bad issue of his counsell vaine,
For euill deedes may better then bad words be bore.
Of gold, that bad eyes might it not prophane:
Himselfe he wisht haue beene, then in so bad a stead.
And bad them leaue their labours and long toyle,
And bad him rise, or surely he should die.
And wearie limmes recur'd after late vsage bad.
And bad them, if so be they were not bound,
Bad them not looke for better entertayne;
She bad to lighten my too heauie band,
Whose bad condition yet it doth retaine,
That both to good and bad he dealeth right,
He bad him stay, and backe with him retire;
And bad his seruant Talus to inuent
For proofe whereof, he bad them Florimell forth call.
For any death to chaunge life though most bad:
She bad that streight the gates should be vnbard,
And better bad aduise, ere they assaid
As a bad Nurse, which fayning to receiue
And tell what euer it be, good or bad,
Cease thou bad newes-man, badly doest thou hide
And mounting to her steede, bad Talus guide her on.
Nor good nor bad, ne euer lookt aside,
Had long surceast, she bad to open bold,
Which late her folke had slaine, she bad the[m] forth to hold.
Bad doe away the dampe of drouzie sleepe,
And would no lenger treat, but bad them sound.
To haue beheld a spectacle so bad:
By his bad wife, that hight Adicia,
By some bad spirit, that it to mischiefe bore,
For the bold title of a Poet bad
And forth he far'd with all his many bad,
And with bold vaunts, and ydle threatning bad
Fallen into that Tyrants hand and vsage bad.
But that those villens through their vsage bad
Bad him auaunt, ne would vnto his lore
Agreeing in bad will and cancred kynd,
But in bad maner they did disagree:
For what so Enuie good or bad did fynd,
And faynes to weaue false tales and leasings bad,
Bad him to flie with all the speed he could,
To be a let, he bad me by and by
He bad him stand, t'abide the bitter stoure
For their bad Stuard neither plough'd nor sowed,
Gainst all, both good and bad, both most and least,
Of all the vile demeane, and vsage bad,
And therefore lightly bad him packe away,
He bad his eyes to be vnblindfold both,
The best aduizement was of bad, to let her
But day, that doth discouer bad and good,
Now made the spoile of theeues and Brigants bad,
Bad them be still, his loue should not be sold:
Boldly him bad such iniurie forbeare;
Of good and bad alike, of low and hie;
But that in stead therof, she sternely bade
For whose sweete sake that glorious badge he wore,
Whiles cursed steele against that badge I bent,
The sacred badge of my Redeemers death,
To loose the badge, that should his deedes display.
His deare Redeemers badge vpon the bosse:
Which is the badge of honour and of fame,
The badges of reproch, he threw away,
With so braue badges one so basely borne;
Seest not, how badly all things present bee,
Cease thou bad newes-man, badly doest thou hide
Who hearing how his people badly sped,
And himselfe baffuld, and his armes vnherst,
Turpine is baffuld, his two knights
And baffuld so, that all which passed by,
Or wearied with bearing of her bag
Vnfitly furnisht with thy bag and booke,
And in this bag which I behinde me don,
Yet is the bottle leake, and bag so torne,
Of that displeasure, broke his bag-pipe quight,
They heard a noyse of many bagpipes shrill,
Then gan the bagpypes and the hornes to shrill,
To fill his bags, and richesse to compare;
Crowned with girlonds of immortall baies,
And in all battels bore away the baies.
Ne none there was to reskue her, ne none to baile.
And thousand other wayes, to bait his fleshly hookes.
As chained Beare, whom cruell dogs do bait,
The fish that once was caught, new bait will hardly bite.
That notwithstanding all the subtill bait,
At night doth baite his steedes the Ocean waues emong.
Vnwares the hidden hooke with baite I swallowed.
Through false allurement of that pleasing baite,
And made the baite of bestiall delight:
As beauties louely baite, that doth procure
They sent that Blatant Beast to be a baite,
And bake their sides vppon the cold hard stone,
Whether shall weigh the balance downe; to weet
And said; Be not vpon thy balance wroken:
And almost would his balances haue broken:
Her craftie head was altogether bald,
But all behind was bald, and worne away,
For light she hated as the deadly bale,
She fed her wound with fresh renewed bale;
Soone as I thinke vpon my bitter bale:
Th'eternall bale of heauie wounded harts;
Yet still he stroue to cloke his inward bale,
Embost with bale, and bitter byting griefe,
That we may pitty such vnhappy bale,
Her faultie Handmayd, which that bale did breede,
Which thee to endlesse bale captiued lead.
Are meet, the which doe men in bale to sterue,
A song of bale and bitter sorrow sings,
As one in wilfull bale for euer buried.
To bring her backe againe, or worke her finall bale.
Full of sad powre, that poysonous bale did breede
Of their vaine prowesse, turned to their proper bale.
To thrall my looser life, or my last bale to breed.
And bring vs bale and bitter sorrowings,
Lay in the lap of death, rewing his wretched bale.
Desired be, or thence to banish bale:
As now the author of thy bale to be,
He cast about, and searcht his balefull bookes againe.
With balefull beggerie, or foule disgrace,
Haue borne him hence to Plutoes balefull bowres.
Begin, and end the bitter balefull stound;
That brought not backe the balefull body dead;
Yet liue perforce in balefull darkenesse bound?
Shrieking his balefull note, which euer draue
The bitter doome of death and balefull mone
Who thereby dead that balefull Beast did deeme,
And in dead parents balefull ashes bred,
With that his balefull speare, he fiercely bent
And of the battell balefull end had made,
First did it shew the bitter balefull stowre,
To enter into that same balefull Bowre,
Into the balefull house of endlesse night,
In balefull night, where all things are forgot;
Brought vnto balefull ruine, was by name
Resolu'd to build his balefull mansion,
Brought thee from balefull house of Proserpine,
Full dreadfull things out of that balefull booke
To ward his bodie from the balefull stound,
Like to the balefull house of lowest hell,
And balefull Oure, late staind with English blood:
Vnto the crooke t'abide the balefull stowre,
What time sad tydings of his balefull smart
Vpon their blisse, and balefull fortune frowne.
And from her balefull minde all care he banished.
Of butchers balefull hand to ground is feld,
But that their blisse he turn'd to balefulnesse:
T'entrap vnwary fooles in their eternall bales.
Her list in strifull termes with him to balke,
Not sparing wight, ne leauing any balke,
Ne euer for rebuke or blame of any balkt.
Bransles, Ballads, virelayes, and verses vaine;
If in true ballance thou wilt weigh thy state:
Whilst thus the case in doubtfull ballance hong,
In equall ballance with due recompence,
And next her selfe her righteous ballance hanging bee.
An huge great paire of ballance in his hand,
First in one ballance set the true aside.
The eare must be the ballance, to decree
His battred ballances in peeces lay,
The doubtfull ballaunce equally to sway,
And right and wrong ylike in equall ballaunce waide.
His credit now in doubtfull ballaunce hong;
And fild his ballaunce full of idle toys:
So would he of the fire one ballaunce make,
Then would he ballaunce heauen and hell together,
For take thy ballaunce, if thou be so wise,
Within his ballaunce, he could way aright.
So he the words into his ballaunce threw,
But streight the winged words out of his ballaunce flew.
Ne would within his ballaunce well abide.
And weighed out in ballaunces so nere,
A trickling streame of Balme, most soueraine
Besmeard with pretious Balme, whose vertuous might
With balme and wine and costly spicery,
They pourd in soueraine balme, and Nectar good,
And powring balme, which he had long puruayd,
Which done, he balmes and herbes thereto applyde,
Gan both enuy, and bitterly to ban;
The pleasant Boyne, the fishy fruitfull Ban,
There gan he me to curse and ban, for lacke
Vpon the banck they sitting did espy
Ne banck nor bush could stay him, when he sped
In wine and meats she flowd aboue the bancke,
One sitting idle on a sunny bancke,
He on the bancke arriu'd with mickle paine,
Next these came Tyne, along whose stony bancke
Stood on the further bancke beholding him,
And in strong banckes his violence enclose,
Ne with th'eternall Gods to bancket come;
In beds, in bowres, in banckets, and in feasts:
And aye the cups their bancks did ouerflow,
Shall driue a Mill, within strong bancks is pent,
But Nymphes and Faeries by the bancks did sit,
Such one was Auarice, the fourth of this faire band.
Huge routs of people did about them band,
With all her band was following the chace,
Aread Prince Arthur, crowne of Martiall band?
There as thou slepst in tender swadling band,
Whom farre before did march a goodly band
But since that band ye cannot now release,
Ere thou thy daughter linck in holy band
By breaking of the band betwixt vs twaine;
Who seeming sorely chauffed at his band,
The vsuall ioyes at knitting of loues band.
And him besought by that same sacred band
Ought thy remembraunce, and perpetuall band
That wicked band of villeins fresh begon
And that fourth band, which cruell battry bent,
Till it dissolued be from earthly band.
From thence, him firmely bound with faithfull band,
A band of Britons ryding on forray
For great despight of that vnwonted band,
He found him not; for he had broke his band,
Why then is Amoret in caytiue band,
For vertue is the band, that bindeth harts most sure.
His wearie ghost assoyld from fleshly band,
And mighty spirites bound with mightier band,
And vauncing forth from all the other band
Thus was Sir Satyrane with all his band
And that late weaker band of chalengers relieued.
Hauing through stirring loosd their wonted band,
That is the crowne of knighthood, and the band
She bad to lighten my too heauie band,
But of them all the band of vertuous mind
Vnwilling to behold that louely band.
Yet often stainde with bloud of many a band
And gnashed with his teeth, as if he band
Ne loose that he hath bound with stedfast band.
Who being freed from Proteus cruell band
So farre he past amongst his enemies band,
And put to that base seruice of her band,
When they haue shaken off the shamefast band,
And her good Knights, of which so braue a band
And curst, and band, and blasphemies forth threw,
He sent to her his basenet, as a faithfull band.
Clad all in gilden armes, with azure band
And whether free with him she now were, or in band.
Such was the beauty of this goodly band,
Yet none of them could euer bring him into band.
Himselfe in streighter bandes too rash implyes,
In captiue bandes, which there they readie found:
It is not yron bandes, nor hundred eyes,
With perfect peace, and bandes of fresh accord,
Witnesse their broken bandes there to be seene,
The pleasaunt Bandon crownd with many a wood,
That soone to loose her wicked bands did her constraine.
That was in sacred bands of wedlocke tyde
Or weaknesse is to sinfull bands made thrall:
Else should this Redcrosse knight in bands haue dyde,
But neither darkenesse fowle, nor filthy bands,
The knights knit friendly bands:
As this good Prince redeemd the Redcrosse knight from bands.
Als flew his steed, as he his bands had brast,
Much more then that, why they in bands were layd,
Till from her bands the spright assoiled is,
My conscience cleare with guilty bands would bind?
Whom Princes late displeasure left in bands,
And gan to breake the bands of their captiuitee.
And threw in bands, where he till death remaind;
Out of his hold, and broke his caitiue bands,
The lothfull life, now loosd from sinfull bands,
Throwing away her broken chaines and bands,
Sweet loue such lewdnes bands from his faire companie.
Proud of his dying honor and deare bands,
He brought to her in bands, as conquered
He reard him vp, and loosd his yron bands,
And her small wast girt round with yron bands,
Allide with bands of mutuall couplement;
In bands of friendship, there did liue for euer,
And bound them with inuiolable bands;
